A series of Nb-based catalysts with different acid types of carriers (TiO2, Beta molecular sieve, and CeO2) were synthesized. In the catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane (DCM), Nb/CeO2 exhibited the best catalytic activity, resistance to chlorine poisoning/carbon deposits, and stability, due to the abundant acid sites and appropriate ratio of Lewis to Bronsted acid sites on the surface. Both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites could participate in the breakdown of C-Cl bonds, whereas the former exerted a greater influence. The Bronsted acid sites participated in the desorption of Cl species, and were prone to the generation of carbon deposits. The chlorine species easily accumulated at the Lewis acid sites of Nb/TiO2(containing predominantly Lewis acid sites), formed metal chlorides, and caused chlorine poisoning. Carbon deposits made it difficult for Nb/Beta (containing predominantly Bronsted acid sites) to maintain long-term activity. Additionally, the acid sites generated by the active component were more important for DCM degradation than those generated by the carrier. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic oxidation Dichloromethane Nb Acid sites Anti-poisoning 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), with high stability and toxicity, adversely affect the ecological environment and human health. Among various CVOC treatment technologies, catalytic combustion has been extensively researched and applied due to its advantages, such as, low temperature, high efficiency, and low secondary pollution. The development and design of catalysts is an integral part of this technology, whereby exploring the relationship between the catalyst microstructure and activity is critical in improving catalytic performance[1,2]. In recent years, an increasing number of researchers have focused on the influence of surface acidity on the catalytic oxidation of CVOCs [3–6]. Wang et al. [7] reported that the degradation of dichloromethane (DCM) on acid catalysts occurs by its adsorption, on the surface acid sites, causing C-Cl bond rupture, followed by oxidation into CH by-products and COx. Aranzabal et al. [8] pointed out that both chlorine poisoning and carbon deposition of molecular sieve catalysts occur at Bronsted (B) acid sites, causing irreversible deactivation of the catalyst. According to Liu et al. [9], surface acidity influences the catalytic oxidation of vinyl chloride due to the redox activity of the catalyst. Although several explanations have been proposed, no definitive conclusion has been reached. Thus, further research into the structure-activity relationship between surface acidity and CVOCs catalyst is warranted. Some pertinent questions that need to be addressed are as follows: Do acid sites from different sources have the same impact on catalytic oxidation? Do differences in the category of surface acidity affect catalytic performance and anti-poisoning? TiO2 is a Lewis (L) acid carrier with abundant acidity, that has been widely applied in the catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. Huang et al. [10] used a CTAB-assisted hydrothermal process to create hollow-structured TiO2 nanoparticles with high catalytic activity for dichloromethane, because of a large number of acid sites. The Beta molecular sieve is a carrier with a high concentration of B acid sites. According to some studies, the B acid is the center of CVOC catalytic oxidation, adsorption, and reaction, and its presence can reduce the production of Cl2 and polychlorinated by-products [8,11]. CeO2 is a redox carrier with few acid sites, and its excellent oxygen storage and release properties can facilitate the deep oxidation of CVOCs [12]. NbOx,including Nb2O5-TiO2 [13], Nb-CeNTs[14], and (Ce,Cr)xO2-Nb2O5 [15], has been extensively studied in the catalytic oxidation of CVOCs, and it can improve the acidity strength and redox performance of the catalyst. This study intends to investigate the catalytic degradation of DCM(used as the target pollutant) by NbOx, assisted by various carriers (L acid carrier: TiO2, B acid carrier: Beta molecular sieve, and redox carrier: CeO2). Characterization methods， such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) were used to investigate the physicochemical properties of the catalyst, analyze the relationship between the acid sites, catalytic activity, and anti-poisoning, and investigate the CVOC degradation mechanism at the acid sites. The physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of TiO2 and CeO2 had been investigated in our published paper[16], and were only used for comparison in this study. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Beta zeolite was supplied by Tianjin Nanhua Catalyst Co., Ltd., while nano-sized anatase TiO2 and pure CeO2 were prepared according to a previously published method[16]. A specific amount of niobium oxalate, a precursor of the active component Nb, was dissolved in deionized water, followed by impregnation into each of the carriers (TiO2, CeO2, and Beta molecular sieves). The mixture was stirred uniformly for several hours at room temperature before drying for 12 h at 80 °C. Subsequently, it was calcined at 450 °C for 3 h to obtain a niobium oxide-supported catalyst. The mass percentage of the active phase was 5%. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku D/MAX-RB diffractometer with a scanning range of 5–80°, which was used to characterize the crystal structure and morphology of the catalysts [17]. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalysts were measured by a nitrogen adsorption apparatus (ASAP 2460 micromeritics). The size and micro-morphology of the catalysts were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI TF20) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried out using an ESCALAB 250X (Thermo Scientific) spectrometer, where the C1s peak of carbon deposits was set at 284.8 eV for charge correction[18]. The ammonia-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were carried out using a TP-5089 multifunctional adsorption instrument (Tianjin Xianquan, China). Initially, the samples were pre-treated in pure He at 350 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, NH3 (4% in He) was introduced for adsorption by the samples until saturation. NH3 desorption was completed by heating the catalysts in He (50 mL/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) studies were performed with the same TP-5089 instrument. The powder sample (0.1 g) was pretreated under an O2/He (5% O2, 30 mL/min) flow in the temperature range of 50–600 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C /min. The signals of Cl2 and HCl were monitored by an online MS (mass spectrum, Hiden Analytical, Ltd.,) at m/z values of 71 and 36, respectively. The adsorption instrument, TP-5089, was also used for hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments. The samples (50 mg) were pretreated in a 3%O2/He flow at 350 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, when the reaction temperature dropped to 30 °C, the samples were heated to 900 °C in a 6% H2/N2 flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. NH3 adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (NH3-FTIR) studies were performed on a Nicolet IS50 FT-IR(ThermoScientific) spectrometer with ZnSe windows. NH3 was introduced at room temperature for catalyst adsorption, followed by sample purging at 100 °C for 1 h, and data collection by the spectrometer. Pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Pyridine-FTIR) studies were carried out with the same FT-IR (Nicolet IS50, ThermoScientific) instrument, equipped with a custom-made IR cell that connected by a vacuum to the adsorption apparatus. The catalysts were pretreated in a He atmosphere for 1 h at 300 °C,followed by injection of, pyridine vapor until adsorption saturation. Pyridine desorption was recorded at 200 °C. Gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS,TRACE1300 GC equipped with ISQ7000 MS, ThermoScientific) was used to qualitatively analyze the reaction by-products. The waste gas at T90 (the reaction temperature required to reach 90% conversion) was collected for 30 min using a Tenax GR adsorption tube at a fixed temperature, then degassed using a thermal desorption apparatus, and analyzed by the GC/MS system equipped with a TG-5SILMS chromatographic column. The TP-5089 instrument was used for temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) experiments. The sample (0.1 g) was pretreated in a He atmosphere at 300 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 30 °C, the mixed gas (DCM (1000 ppm), O2(5%), He) was injected at 50 mL/min and heated from 50 to 400 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The reaction products in the tail gas, such as CO, CO2, HCl, and Cl2,were collected by the mass spectrometer. Nicolet IS50 FT-IR spectrometer (ThermoScientific) was used for in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies. The catalysts were pretreated in a He flow (100 mL/min) at 350 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the spectra were recorded at various temperatures under the mixed gas composition (1000 ppm DCM,10 vol% O2, and balance N2). 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements Catalytic activity was measured in a fixed-bed at 200°C-360°C with the catalyst sieved to 40–60 mesh, and mixed with quartz sand of the same mesh, to a filling volume of 2 mL, with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20000/h. The gas composition for the catalytic reaction was 1000 ppm CH2Cl2, 10%O2, and balance N2. The concentrations of CH2Cl2, CO, and CO2 were measured and calculated by gas chromatography [19]. DCM conversion(X) was calculated using the following equation: X DCM % = [DCM] in - [DCM] out [DCM] in × 100 % in which [DCM]in and [DCM]out are the concentrations of CH2Cl2 at the inlet and outlet, respectively. In this study, the concentration of the by-products were calculated by the carbon balance, [DCM]in-[DCM]out-[CO]-[CO2]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis of the structure of catalysts The XRD patterns of the catalysts (Nb/TiO2, Nb/Beta, and Nb/CeO2) corresponded to the typical diffraction peaks of pure anatase TiO2, BEA zeolite and fluorite cubic CeO2 respectively ( Fig. 1) [20]. Furthermore, no characteristic diffraction peaks of Nb or niobium oxide were observed in the carrier spectra. Table 1 and Fig. S1 show the specific surface area and pore structure distribution of the catalysts. The Nb/Beta catalyst exhibited the largest specific surface area, followed by Nb/TiO2, and Nb/CeO2. TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) experiments were used to further investigate the morphologies and structures of the catalysts. In Fig. S2, the three catalysts showed irregular nanoparticle morphology with average particle sizes of 10–20 nm. The interplanar spacing of 0.393, 0.356, and 0.310 nm were consistent with the (001) plane of Nb2O5, (101) plane of TiO2, and (111) plane of CeO2, respectively [13,15]. The interplanar spacing of 0.399 nm and 0.303 nm could be assigned to the Beta molecular sieve [21]. It should be noted that the actual spacings in Nb/TiO2 and Nb/CeO2 were slightly larger or smaller than the theoretical interplanar spacings of the (101) plane in pure TiO2 (d=0.352) and the (111) plane in pure CeO2 (d=0.312), respectively. This lattice expansion or contraction could be ascribed to the incorporation of Nb cations into the TiO2 or CeO2 lattice. No such lattice change was observed for the Nb/Beta catalyst. 3.2 Analysis of the catalyst surface elements The chemical states and surface chemical composition of the catalysts were characterized by XPS measurements and the results are shown in Fig. 2. Referring to the relevant literature, the two peaks were centered around 207.1 and 209.7 eV, with a spin-orbit splitting of 2.6 eV in the Nb3d spectrum, corresponded to the Nb5+ species of the Nb3d5/2 orbital and the Nb3d3/2 orbital respectively[22]. Fig. 2(b) illustrates the O1s spectra of each catalyst. For Nb/TiO2 and Nb/CeO2, the binding energies (BE) in the range of 529.6–530.1, 531.5–531.6 and 532.5–533.0 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen (labeled Oa), chemically adsorbed oxygen (labeled Ob), and surface weakly bound oxygen (labeled Oc, including the CxOy species, consisting of adsorbed molecular water and hydroxyl (OH-), respectively [23]. The XPS spectra of Nb/Beta showed four divided peaks located at 531.2 (labeled Oa-Al), 532.7 (labeled Oa-Si), 533.3 (labeled Ob), and 533.7 eV (labeled Oc). The lattice oxygen in aluminates and silicates was assigned to the Oa-Al and Oa-Si respectively [24]. The oxygen species represented by Ob and Oc were consistent with those in Nb/CeO2 and Nb/TiO2. As shown in Fig. 2(b), the oxygen species in the three catalysts, whose main components were metal oxidation and metal salt, primarily existed in the form of lattice oxygen (Oa). Significantly, the molecular sieve carrier catalyst Nb/Beta contained more surface weakly bound oxygen (Oc), due to the abundant Al-OH bonds and Si-OH bonds on its surface [11]. As shown in Table S1, the content of chemically adsorbed oxygen (Ob) on the Nb/CeO2, Nb/Beta, and Nb/TiO2 was 19.70%, 9.02%, and 9.87% respectively. The redox cycle of the active phase benefits from a large amount of chemically adsorbed oxygen [25]. Thus, among the three catalysts, Nb/CeO2 with the highest content of chemically adsorbed oxygen should exhibit the highest redox activity. 3.3 Analysis of catalyst reducibility H2-TPR experiments were used to evaluate the redox performance of the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 3. The H2-TPR profiles of the three catalysts were significantly different. For Nb/TiO2, two hydrogen consumption peaks at 500 and 762 °C were observed, the former peak was attributed to the reduction of the surface oxygen from NbOx and surface TiO2 [13], and the latter peak was attributed to the reduction of bulk TiO2 [26]. The hydrogen consumption peak on the Nb/Beta catalyst was not immediately visible, indicating poor redox performance; however, after magnifying the H2-TPR spectrum, a small peak was observed near 585 °C, which could be assigned to the reduction of NbOx [13]. For Nb/CeO2, two reduction peaks were observed below 600 °C, and the reduction peaks at 408 and 533 °C could be attributed to the reduction of surface CeO2 and that of Nb2O5, respectively. In addition, the reduction peak of bulk CeO2 was observed at 754 °C[27]. Thus, Nb/CeO2 exhibited a lower reduction temperature and larger area of the reduction peak than the other two catalysts, indicating that the strongest redox activity. This was favorable for the deep oxidation of the organic reactants and byproducts. 3.4 Analysis of the surface acidity of the catalysts The surface acidity of the catalysts was analyzed by NH3-TPD. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the Beta molecular sieve and TiO2 exhibited strong acidity and adsorption of ammonia. The Beta molecular sieve continuously exhibited two ammonia desorption peaks in the range of 200–700 °C, indicating that the catalyst contained a large amount of weak, medium-strong and strong acid, whereas the ammonia desorption peak of TiO2 extended from 200 °C to 600 °C, indicating the predominance of weak acid and medium-strong acid. Nb/CeO2, on the other hand, showed no ammonia desorption peak, consistent with its weak acidity. The acidity intensity of the three carriers exhibited different variations on Nb addition. After being supported by niobium oxide, CeO2 (originally with weak acidity) exhibited intense ammonia desorption peaks, indicating acidity enhancement; while the acid carriers (titanium-based, molecular sieve carrier) exhibited no significant changes in the shape and intensity of the ammonia desorption peaks. According to related reports, niobium oxide species are acidic, and the doping of niobium can increase the number of L and B acid sites on the catalyst [28]. However, the surface acidity of the Nb-supported acid carriers did not change significantly in this study. Further experimentation was carried out to clarify if this was due to a variation in the number of acid sites. NH3-FTIR studies were used to investigate surface acidity of the catalysts before and after Nb doping. The results are shown in Fig. 4(b,c,d). The peaks at 1639–1519, 1346–1099, and 1176–1155 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric deformation vibrations of NH3 coordinated at the L acid sites [29]. The absorption peaks at 1851–1637 cm−1 and 1525–1356 cm−1 corresponded to the deformation vibrations of NH4 + adsorbed on the B acid sites. TiO2 contained numerous L acid sites on its surface before Nb doping, mainly produced by Ti4+; and a few B acid sites. The Beta molecular sieve contained a high concentration of B and L acid sites, with a predominance of B acid sites. The B acid sites were provided by the Si-OH-Al bridging hydroxyl groups of the molecular sieve carrier [8], whereas the L acid sites were attributed to the aluminum ions outside the framework. CeO2 is a redox carrier with a limited number of acid sites (predominantly L acid sites)[30]. The addition of Nb affected the various types of carriers differently. The Nb species contributed a significant number of L acid and B acid sites to the weakly acid CeO2 sample, generated by NbO and Nb-OH formation respectively [31]. The combination of TiO2 with Nb decreased the number of L acid sites slightly and increased the number of B acid sites, with L acid sites being predominat. On doping Beta with Nb, the number of L acid sites decreased slightly, while the number of B acid sites increased, with a higher proportion of B acid sites overall. Related studies have reported that the total acid content of Cr-O/HZSM5 gradually decreased with the increase in Cr content, owing to the occupation of some acid sites by Cr[32]. In this study, although the addition of Nb increased the L acid and B acid sites, for acid carriers, the active-phase Nb species could occupy the acid sites (particularly the L acid sites) on the carrier surfaces, thereby consuming them. Additionally, the number of L acid sites consumed were greater than those created by Nb doping. As shown in Table S2, the number of Lewis and Bronsted acid sites were calculated by analyzing the infrared spectra of the catalysts (peaks at 1445 and 1540 cm−1 for the L and B acid, respectively) after pyridine adsorption [11]. The total amount of acid in Nb/Beta, Nb/TiO2 and Nb/CeO2 was 0.340, 0.159 and 0.078 mmol/g, respectively. While the order of the ratio of L acid sites to B acid sites was in the following order: Nb/TiO2(6.57) > Nb/CeO2(3.11) > Nb/Beta (0.98). 3.5 Investigation of the catalytic degradation of DCM and stability of the catalysts Fig. 5 shows the catalytic oxidation activity of different niobium oxide-supported carriers (TiO2, CeO2, Beta molecular sieve) for DCM degradation. Before Nb addition, the TiO2 and Beta molecular sieve carriers, with abundant acid sites on the surface exhibited significantly higher DCM conversion than the CeO2 sample. The addition of Nb improved the catalyst activity to varying degrees. Nb/CeO2 showed the highest catalytic activity, with 96.2% DCM conversion at 315 °C, and almost complete degradation at 330 °C (above 99%DCM conversion). The Nb/TiO2 catalyst exhibited high initial catalytic activity in the temperature range of 200–275 °C, with 92.5% DCM conversion at 280 °C. However, its catalytic activity reduced significantly on increasing temperature. DCM conversion by the Nb-supported Beta molecular sieve in the low-temperature region (less than 275 °C) changed negligibly on addition of Nb, but it increased rapidly after 275 °C and the DCM conversion could exceeded 95% at 355 °C. Combining the above-mentioned characterization by NH3-TPD and NH3-IR, it can be concluded that the acid sites were important active sites for DCM degradation, as they facilitated the adsorption of DCM and the rupture of C-Cl bonds. The combination of CeO2 (with fewer acid sites) with Nb increased the number of L and B acid sites significantly, facilitated the DCM conversion. Additionally, TiO2 (containing predominantly L acid sites) and Beta molecular sieve (containing predominantly B acid sites) had a greater impact towards DCM conversion, indicated the influence of both L acid and B acid in the degradation of DCM. Furthermore, in the temperature range of 200–300 °C, the activity of the catalysts containing predominantly L acid sites (TiO2, Nb/TiO2) were significantly higher than those containing predominantly B acid sites (Beta, Nb/Beta). Thus, L acid sites exert a greater influence on DCM degradation than B acid sites, especially at low temperature. It is known that the acid sites of Nb-based catalysts are predominantly derived from both the active components and the carrier. Based on the aforementioned conclusions, assuming that DCM conversion was all measured by acid sites, the contribution of the acid sites on Nb-based catalysts towards DCM degradation was calculated ( Fig. 6). The calculation procedure was described in supplementary material (Table S3). For these three catalysts investigated, the acid sites of the active components of Nb exhibited a greater contribution towards the degradation of DCM than did the carriers (Ti, Ce or Si+Al). Therefore, it can be speculated that the acid sites produced by the active component NbOx influence the degradation of DCM more strongly than the acid sites of the carriers. To investigate the complete oxidation of DCM by the niobium oxide-supported catalysts, the product distribution in the tail gas was analyzed, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8. As shown in Fig. 7, for the Nb/TiO2 catalyst, a large number of by-products were formed, with a concentration of up to 757 ppm at 275 °C; with an increase in temperature, the formation of by-products gradually decreased, with approximately 400 ppm by-products at 360 °C; A small amount of COx was generated in the entire temperature range analyzed. The concentration of by-products on Nb/Beta gradually increased with the increase of temperature, reaching about 500 ppm at 355 °C, with 350 ppm concentration of COx. Very few by-products were generated on the Nb/CeO2 catalyst, with a majority of the intermediate by-products being converted to CO and CO2. At 355 °C, the tail gas contained predominantly COx, with only a trace of DCM and intermediate by-products. Therefore, Nb/CeO2 exhibited strong redox performance, conducive to the deep oxidation of by-products, to produce COx. This was consistent with the XPS and H2-TPR results. The results of GC-MS (see Fig. 8(a)) indicated that the major by-products of Nb/TiO2 and Nb/Beta were CH3Cl and CHCl3, along with small amounts of CCl4, C2HCl3 and C2Cl4. The main by-product of Nb/CeO2 was CH3Cl, but its amount was significantly lower than that of Nb/TiO2 and Nb/Beta, with negligible formation of the other by-products (CHCl3, CCl4, C2HCl3,and C2Cl4). It further demonstrates that the strong redox property of Nb/CeO2 promoted the deep degradation of by-products, inhibiting the formation of polychlorinated products. DCM-TPSR experiments were performed to determine the dechlorination ability of a catalysts. According to Fig. 8(b-d), HCl was obviously detected after 240 °C, but no distinct peak of Cl2 was observed for Nb/TiO2, Nb/CeO2 and Nb/Beta. The hydroxyl group in the B acid sites could react with chlorine species to generate HCl, which promoted the desorption of Cl species [29]. This could explain the production of a large amount of HCl above 200 °C by the Nb/Beta catalyst (containing predominantly B acid sites). Unexpectedly, the tail gases for all the three catalysts contained predominantly CO, with small amount of CO2 at high temperature. The stability of the three catalysts was investigated for 20 h. The test temperature was set to the temperature at which the DCM conversion of each catalyst reached approximately 95%. As shown in Fig. 9, within 1 h, the catalytic activity of Nb/TiO2 decreased rapidly, with the DCM conversion reducing from 94.6% to 32.4%. The Nb/Beta molecular sieve was also deactivated rapidly. In contrast, Nb/CeO2 exhibited good stability, with the DCM conversion maintained at above 94.0% (at 315 °C), and there was no significant reduction in catalytic activity. 3.6 The analysis of anti-poisoning As shown in Table 2, XPS analysis of Nb/TiO2, Nb/CeO2,and Nb/Beta, after DCM-degradation experiments at T95 indicated surface-Cl atomic concentrations of up to 5.45%,1.60%, and 1.56%, respectively. In the TPO curves of the three used catalysts shown in Fig.S3 (a), only one broad desorption peak of HCl was observed in the range of 50–250 °C. The order of the intensity of HCl desorption peaks was as follows: Nb/Beta > Nb/CeO2 > Nb/TiO2. At around 500 °C, there was a significant Cl2 desorption peak for Nb/TiO2, while no such peaks appeared for the other two catalysts (Fig.S3 (b)). This could be attributed to the reaction of the chlorine species adsorbed on the L acid sites of the used Nb/TiO2 catalyst with metal ions to form metal chlorides, resulting in the desorption of chlorine species in the form of Cl2 at high temperature [19]. For Nb/CeO2 and Nb/Beta, since the chlorine species existing on the surface did not react significantly with the catalysts, they could easily desorb in the form of HCl at low temperature. Thus, the Nb/TiO2 catalyst was deactivated in both the activity test and the stability test, owing to the adsorption and accumulation of chlorine species on its L acid sites, formation of metal chlorides, and inability of the chlorine species to get desorbed over time. Despite the presence of B acid sites, they were far fewer in number than the L acid sites, implying that their influence on the desorption of Cl species could be weak and insufficient to prevent chlorine poisoning. The Nb/Beta catalyst had good resistance to chlorine poisoning and showed no deactivation in the activity test, which could be attributed to the abundance of B acid sites in the molecular sieve. However, the catalytic activity of the Nb/Beta catalyst decreased during the stability test. According to Table 2, the increase in surface-C atomic concentrations (ΔC=12.07%) in the fresh and used Nb/Beta catalyst was significantly higher than that of the other two catalysts. A possible explanation could be that for Nb/Beta (containing predominantly B acid), the by-products of the reaction easily accumulated at B acid sites, forming carbon deposits on the catalyst surface, causing rapid deactivation [8]. In the case of the Nb/CeO2 catalyst, the carrier CeO2 itself has certain anti-chlorine poisoning properties [33]. Furthermore, the appropriate ratio of L acid sites to B acid sites on the Nb/CeO2 catalyst surface played a significant role in anti-poisoning. The sufficient B acid sites could react with Cl species to produce HCl, facilitating the desorption of the Cl species [29]. At the same time, the content of B acid site on the catalyst surface was insufficient to cause carbon deposition and deactivation. Thus, Nb/CeO2 was highly resistant to chlorine poisoning, and exhibited good stability in long-term activity tests. 3.7 Research on the reaction mechanism In-situ infrared spectroscopy studies were used to elucidate the degradation of DCM by Nb/CeO2, Nb/TiO2, and Nb/Beta. As shown in Fig. 10, on introduction of DCM and O2 at 100 °C, infrared peaks at 3069, 3027, 1628, 1270 and 1267 cm−1 were observed on the surfaces of Nb/CeO2, Nb/TiO2, and Nb/Beta. These peaks corresponded to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of CH2 in the CH2Cl2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and disappeared on increasing temperature [34,35]. The infrared peaks appeared at 2941, 2929, 2866, and 2840 cm−1 belong to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of CH3 in the CH3O group [36,37]. Furthermore, the infrared peaks of Nb/Beta at 1492 and 1458 cm−1 corresponded to the adsorption peaks of formic acid species [25]. On increasing the reaction temperature to 200 °C, the intensity of the infrared peaks at 2941, 2929, 2866 and 2840 cm−1 increased. Nb/CeO2 and Nb/TiO2 revealed new infrared peaks at 1650, 1590, 1381, 1355, and 1320 cm−1, which were attributed to the vibration peaks of COO and CH in the adsorbed HCOO group [28], These peaks were not found on Nb/Beta. At 250 °C, the infrared peak intensity corresponded to the formate groups on Nb/CeO2 catalyst weakened, whereas that on the Nb/TiO2 catalyst continued to increase. For the Nb/Beta catalyst, new infrared peaks were observed at 1700 and 1584 cm−1, corresponded to the stretching vibrations of CO of formaldehyde (HCHO) and the vibrations of COO and CH in the adsorbed HCOO group respectively. According to related research [38], some of the intermediate products formed after DCM dechlorination form HCHO in the adsorbed state on the surface of molecular sieve catalysts, which disproportionated under acid catalysis to the formate and methoxy groups [39]. The two peaks in the Nb/Beta spectrum continued to increase with the increasing temperature. It could be speculated that due to its strong redox performance, Nb/CeO2 can rapidly and deeply oxidized the intermediate by-products produced in the degradation of DCM, while this was not possible in the case of Nb/TiO2 and Nb/Beta because of their weak redox performance, resulting in the accumulation of by-products. Furthermore, at high temperature, Nb/Beta exhibited a new peak at 3123 cm−1,corresponded to the olefin absorption peak. The proclivity of the Nb/Beta catalyst for carbon deposition was demonstrated by the ease with which the olefin causes triggers chain growth and carbon deposition [40]. To sum up, the main intermediate by-products produced by the three catalysts (Nb/TiO2, Nb/CeO2, and Nb/Beta) in the catalytic oxidation process were the formate (HCOO) and methoxy (CH3O) groups, with the Nb/Beta molecular sieve additionally producing formaldehyde (HCHO). Therefore, based on this study, as well as other studies on the DCM reaction mechanism, two reaction paths were proposed. The possible reaction paths of Nb/CeO2 and Nb/TiO2 are shown in Fig. 11(a)(b): the C-Cl bonds in CH2Cl2 were simultaneously broken at the L and B acid sites to directly produce dimethoxy groups, which were then oxidized into formate groups or disproportionated to generate the formate (HCOO) and methoxy (CH3O) groups [36]. The aforementioned groups can be completely degraded into the final products (CO2/CO and H2O) on Nb/CeO2, but only partially on Nb/TiO2. Furthermore, because of the combined effect of CeO2 and B acid sites on Nb/CeO2, chlorine species can be rapidly desorbed, inhibiting chlorine poisoning of the catalyst, enabling maintenance of its high catalytic activity. The reaction path of Nb/Beta was slightly different (Fig. 11(c). DCM generated dimethoxy groups after the removal of one molecule of HCl, followed by their conversion into HCHO in the adsorbed state. Subsequently, HCHO could be disproportionated under acid catalysis to formate and methoxy groups, which can only be partially degraded into CO2/CO and H2O, Thus, carbon deposits were formed on the surface of the catalyst and made it inactive. 4 Conclusion In a word, the influence of acid sites on the catalytic activity and anti-poisoning performance of the catalysts can be summarized as follows: Both L and B acid sites on the catalyst surface facilitated the adsorption of DCM and the rupture of C-Cl bonds, immensely influenced the degradation of DCM. The L acid sites influenced DCM degradation to a greater extent than the B acid sites. Furthermore, the B acid sites could combine with Cl species to generate HCl, which facilitated the desorption of Cl species and played an important role in anti-chlorine poisoning. Therefore, the Nb/CeO2 catalyst, with abundant acid sites on its surface and the appropriate ratio of L acid sites to B acid sites, showed the best catalytic performance, resistance to chlorine poisoning and stability: it completely degraded DCM at 330 °C, completely converted the by-products into COx at 355 °C, and maintained good activity in the 20 h stability test. However, the Nb/TiO2 catalyst (with predominantly L acid sites) exhibited deactivation in both the activity and stability tests. The primary reason was chlorine poisoning of the catalyst due to the accumulation of chlorine species at the L acid sites and the formation of metal chlorides. The Nb/Beta catalyst (with predominantly B acid sites) only exhibited deactivation in the stability test, mainly resulting from carbon deposits generated by the enrichment of by-products at the B acid sites. Furthermore, the contribution of the acid sites produced by the active component NbOx and the carrier to the degradation of DCM was calculated using the XPS results. The acid sites produced by the active component influenced the degradation of DCM to a greater extent than those produced by the carrier. Thus, while adjusting the acid sites of a CVOC catalyst, it is important to consider the source of the acid sites as well as the relative content of Land B acid to avoid chlorine poisoning and carbon deposits on the catalyst. This effective strategy for improvement of catalytic performance and stability could facilitate the development and design of new catalysts for the efficient degradation of CVOCs, with numerous potential applications, including environmental remediation. coredata.dc:description: A series of Nb-based catalysts with different acid types of carriers (TiO2, Beta molecular sieve, and CeO2) were synthesized. In the catalytic oxidation of dichloromethane (DCM), Nb/CeO2 exhibited the best catalytic activity, resistance to chlorine poisoning/carbon deposits, and stability, due to the abundant acid sites and appropriate ratio of Lewis to Bronsted acid sites on the surface. Both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites could participate in the breakdown of C-Cl bonds, whereas the former exerted a greater influence. The Bronsted acid sites participated in the desorption of Cl species, and were prone to the generation of carbon deposits. The chlorine species easily accumulated at the Lewis acid sites of Nb/TiO2(containing predominantly Lewis acid sites), formed metal chlorides, and caused chlorine poisoning. Carbon deposits made it difficult for Nb/Beta (containing predominantly Bronsted acid sites) to maintain long-term activity. Additionally, the acid sites generated by the active component were more important for DCM degradation than those generated by the carrier.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insights into the role of acidity to activity and anti-poisoning over Nb based catalysts for CVOCs combustion
